reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s fat-tail/value-efficiency move in §3.2, which is one important route to “linear views are fussy” (narrow target due to highly concentrated value-efficiency). However, the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion is also supported by multiple other strands (fragility/product-of-factors framing, bounded-view arguments, goods/bads aggregation), so even fully defusing this would not collapse the position; hence moderate centrality. On the attacked sub-claim, the critique makes a substantive point that empirical fat tails in wealth/citations/popularity are driven by mechanisms not clearly tracking moral value, and that fat-tailedness alone doesn’t entail that almost-all resources must be used in an almost-exactly optimal way (near-optima could be plentiful). These objections meaningfully weaken the inference but don’t fully refute it, since the original argument also invokes separability + vast design space + uncertainty and could be rebuilt with different support. Most statements are plausible/correct (especially the logical point about fat tails not implying extreme concentration of optimality mass), with some empirical speculation (e.g., fat tails shrinking with maturity) that is reasonable but not clearly established. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little filler.
title: Fat-tailed empirical distributions do not establish fat-tailed moral value
